clusters.title: How employers can help their staff stay in work | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Employers and Health Support for Workers Discussed

items.title: How employers can help their staff stay in work | Letters
items.standfirst: Readers respond to the government’s Keep Britain Working review that aims to tackle the growing worklessness crisisThe Keep Britain Working review highlights the crisis of people leaving the labour market because of poor health (Fixing Britain’s worklessness crisis will cost employers £6bn a year, report says, 5 November). Its call for employers to improve occupational health support and early intervention is welcome, but it risks missing the bigger issue: work itself.For too long, the UK has subsidised poor work. Public authorities have awarded contracts to employers that pay low wages, offer insecure hours and provide little support when people fall ill. The state then picks up the cost in welfare, lost tax and pressure on the NHS. That’s not a sustainable economy, it’s a subsidy for failure. Continue reading...
items.content: Readers respond to the government’s Keep Britain Working review that aims to tackle the growing worklessness crisisThe Keep Britain Working review highlights the crisis of people leaving the labour market because of poor health (Fixing Britain’s worklessness crisis will cost employers £6bn a year, report says, 5 November). Its call for employers to improve occupational health support and early intervention is welcome, but it risks missing the bigger issue: work itself.For too long, the UK has subsidised poor work. Public authorities have awarded contracts to employers that pay low wages, offer insecure hours and provide little support when people fall ill. The state then picks up the cost in welfare, lost tax and pressure on the NHS. That’s not a sustainable economy, it’s a subsidy for failure. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A review highlights people leaving the labor market due to poor health, a growing crisis.
The review calls for employers to improve occupational health support and early intervention.
The UK has subsidized poor work, leading to welfare costs and NHS pressure.
Public authorities have awarded contracts with low wages and insecure hours.
The current system is a subsidy for failure, not a sustainable economy.

clusters.title: Beans, beans, the magical fruit: how healthy are they really?
clusters.neutral_headline: Beans: Healthy Food for Body and Planet

items.title: Beans, beans, the magical fruit: how healthy are they really?
items.standfirst: Research shows beans are good for the body and for the planet. Here’s what to know about getting more in your dietBeans are affordable, accessible and versatile – delicious in dense salads and creamy sauces alike.They grow worldwide and are good for the planet, enriching the soil they sprout from with nitrogen while emitting fewer greenhouse gases and requiring significantly less land and water per gram of protein than any animal source. Thanks to enormous diversity, more than 400 varieties are used in culinary contexts, some of which are gorgeous to boot. Continue reading...
items.content: Research shows beans are good for the body and for the planet. Here’s what to know about getting more in your dietBeans are affordable, accessible and versatile – delicious in dense salads and creamy sauces alike.They grow worldwide and are good for the planet, enriching the soil they sprout from with nitrogen while emitting fewer greenhouse gases and requiring significantly less land and water per gram of protein than any animal source. Thanks to enormous diversity, more than 400 varieties are used in culinary contexts, some of which are gorgeous to boot. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Research shows beans are beneficial for both the human body and the environment.
Beans are affordable, accessible, and versatile for various culinary uses.
They enrich soil with nitrogen and emit fewer greenhouse gases than animal sources.
Over 400 bean varieties exist, used in diverse culinary contexts worldwide.
Beans require less land and water per gram of protein compared to animal sources.

clusters.title: 'Choking' in porn has become the new normal. Here’s why a new UK law banning it is so vital | Clare McGlynn
clusters.neutral_headline: Choking' in porn has become the new normal. Here’s why a new UK law banning it is so vital | Clare McGlynn: Strangulation during sex damages young women’s brain health and breeds deep gender inequality. But the real test will be its enforcement

items.title: 'Choking' in porn has become the new normal. Here’s why a new UK law banning it is so vital | Clare McGlynn
items.standfirst: Strangulation during sex damages young women’s brain health and breeds deep gender inequality. But the real test will be its enforcementThis week marks a turning point in the UK’s approach to violent porn. The government has announced it will make publishing or possessing pornographic depictions of strangulation or suffocation – often known as “choking” – illegal. This bold move could transform the porn that appears on porn sites and social media platforms.Strangulation in porn was once niche. Indeed, studies investigating the content of porn 20 years ago found hardly any instances of it. Yet an independent review of pornography released this year found that it was rife on the most popular porn sites. This summer the children’s commissioner released a report revealing that 58% of young people had seen strangulation in pornography, even though only 6% had searched for it. As renowned porn producer Erika Lust puts it, strangulation has become the “alpha and omega” of “any porn scene”.Clare McGlynn is a professor of law at Durham University and author of Exposed: The Rise of Extreme Porn and How We Fight Back (out in 2026)Do you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a response of up to 300 words by email to be considered for publication in our letters section, please click here. Continue reading...
items.content: Strangulation during sex damages young women’s brain health and breeds deep gender inequality. But the real test will be its enforcementThis week marks a turning point in the UK’s approach to violent porn. The government has announced it will make publishing or possessing pornographic depictions of strangulation or suffocation – often known as “choking” – illegal. This bold move could transform the porn that appears on porn sites and social media platforms.Strangulation in porn was once niche. Indeed, studies investigating the content of porn 20 years ago found hardly any instances of it. Yet an independent review of pornography released this year found that it was rife on the most popular porn sites. This summer the children’s commissioner released a report revealing that 58% of young people had seen strangulation in pornography, even though only 6% had searched for it. As renowned porn producer Erika Lust puts it, strangulation has become the “alpha and omega” of “any porn scene”.Clare McGlynn is a professor of law at Durham University and author of Exposed: The Rise of Extreme Porn and How We Fight Back (out in 2026)Do you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a response of up to 300 words by email to be considered for publication in our letters section, please click here. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The UK government will make publishing or possessing pornographic depictions of strangulation illegal.
Strangulation in porn has become prevalent on popular pornographic websites and social media.
A recent review found strangulation is rife on the most popular porn sites.
A children's commissioner report revealed 58% of young people have seen strangulation in porn.
Clare McGlynn is a professor of law at Durham University and author of a book on extreme porn.

clusters.title: Woman with stage 4 cancer has welfare benefit stopped after falling ill abroad

items.title: Woman with stage 4 cancer has welfare benefit stopped after falling ill abroad
items.standfirst: Ana Paula Cabral’s universal credit payments were abruptly ended by DWP when she failed to return from Portugal tripA woman with stage 4 colon cancer has had her universal credit payments stopped and is at risk of losing her home after she fell ill while visiting family abroad to tell them about her diagnosis.Ana Paula Cabral, 65, who moved to the UK from Portugal eight years ago, started receiving universal credit (UC) in July as she was unable to work after her cancer diagnosis, which required extensive chemotherapy. Continue reading...
items.content: Ana Paula Cabral’s universal credit payments were abruptly ended by DWP when she failed to return from Portugal tripA woman with stage 4 colon cancer has had her universal credit payments stopped and is at risk of losing her home after she fell ill while visiting family abroad to tell them about her diagnosis.Ana Paula Cabral, 65, who moved to the UK from Portugal eight years ago, started receiving universal credit (UC) in July as she was unable to work after her cancer diagnosis, which required extensive chemotherapy. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A woman with stage 4 cancer had her universal credit payments stopped.
The woman, Ana Paula Cabral, is at risk of losing her home.
She fell ill while visiting family in Portugal to share her diagnosis.
Cabral moved to the UK from Portugal eight years ago.
She started receiving universal credit after her cancer diagnosis.

items.standfirst: Resident doctors in England to strike for five days next week, saying health secretary’s latest offer is too limitedWes Streeting has failed in an attempt to end the long-running resident doctors’ dispute with a new offer to them, which means their five-day strike next week is expected to go ahead.The health secretary tabled a new offer to resident doctors – formerly junior doctors – in England on Wednesday in a move intended to avoid the strike, their 13th. ai_summary: Resident doctors in England will proceed with a five-day strike next week.

The strike will be the 13th industrial action taken by resident doctors.
The health secretary's attempt to avert the strike was unsuccessful.
